trans-unit.source: Loops in SQL Data Warehouse | Microsoft Azure
trans-unit.target: Loops in SQL Data Warehouse | Microsoft Azure

trans-unit.source: Tips for Transact-SQL loops and replacing cursors in Azure SQL Data Warehouse for developing solutions.
trans-unit.target: Tips for Transact-SQL loops and replacing cursors in Azure SQL Data Warehouse for developing solutions.

trans-unit.source: SQL Data Warehouse supports the <linkText>WHILE</linkText><title></title> loop for repeatedly executing statement blocks.
trans-unit.target: SQL Data Warehouse supports the <linkText>WHILE</linkText><title></title> loop for repeatedly executing statement blocks.

trans-unit.source: This will continue for as long as the specified conditions are true or until the code specifically terminates the loop using the BREAK keyword.
trans-unit.target: This will continue for as long as the specified conditions are true or until the code specifically terminates the loop using the BREAK keyword.

trans-unit.source: Loops are particularly useful for replacing cursors defined in SQL code.
trans-unit.target: Loops are particularly useful for replacing cursors defined in SQL code.

trans-unit.source: Fortunately, almost all cursors that are written in SQL code are of the fast forward, read only variety.
trans-unit.target: Fortunately, almost all cursors that are written in SQL code are of the fast forward, read only variety.

trans-unit.source: Therefore [WHILE] loops are a great alternative if you find yourself having to replace one.
trans-unit.target: Therefore [WHILE] loops are a great alternative if you find yourself having to replace one.

trans-unit.source: However, before diving in head first you should ask yourself the following question: "Could this cursor be re-written to use set based operations?".
trans-unit.target: However, before diving in head first you should ask yourself the following question: "Could this cursor be re-written to use set based operations?".

trans-unit.source: In many cases the answer will be yes.
trans-unit.target: In many cases the answer will be yes.

trans-unit.source: More often than not the best approach is to do just that.
trans-unit.target: More often than not the best approach is to do just that.

trans-unit.source: A set based operation will often perform significantly faster than an iterative row by row approach.
trans-unit.target: A set based operation will often perform significantly faster than an iterative row by row approach.

trans-unit.source: Fast forward read only cursors can be easily replaced with a looping construct.
trans-unit.target: Fast forward read only cursors can be easily replaced with a looping construct.

trans-unit.source: Below is a simple example to convey the approach.
trans-unit.target: Below is a simple example to convey the approach.

trans-unit.source: The code example updates the statistics for every table in the database.
trans-unit.target: The code example updates the statistics for every table in the database.

trans-unit.source: By iterating over the tables in the loop we are able to execute each command in sequence.
trans-unit.target: By iterating over the tables in the loop we are able to execute each command in sequence.

trans-unit.source: Firstly, create a temporary table containing a unique row number used to identify the individual statements:
trans-unit.target: Firstly, create a temporary table containing a unique row number used to identify the individual statements:

trans-unit.source: Secondly, initialize the variables required to perform the loop:
trans-unit.target: Secondly, initialize the variables required to perform the loop:

trans-unit.source: Now loop over statements executing them one at a time:
trans-unit.target: Now loop over statements executing them one at a time:

trans-unit.source: Finally drop the temporary table created in the first step
trans-unit.target: Finally drop the temporary table created in the first step

trans-unit.target: For more development tips, see <linkText>development overview</linkText><title></title>.
